result.execSummary:
Andrew James Quinn was extradited to another county, state or jurisdiction. Extradition means Andrew James Quinn was accused or convicted of an offense in another county, state or jurisdiction and was taken there to face their charge(s) or conviction.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Andrew James Quinn

records.addlTxt:
9:31 AM Defendant Andrew James Quinn appeared by video, Attorney Jeffrey Warren Erickson appeared by video for Andrew James Quinn, Attorney Luke Steiner appeared by video for State of Wisconsin. 
     Atty. Steiner states Def. to plead to count 1, State moves to dismiss other charges; does not recommend a prison sentence.  Atty. Erickson agrees, as does the Def.
     Court reviews plea agreement with Def.  Def. chooses to have hrg. via ZOOM as wanted to resolve matter quickly; understands he has a right to have hrg. in person.  Court reviews plea questionnaire with Def.
     Def. enters a guilty plea.  Court explains plea.  Def. states understanding.
     Court accepts plea, makes finding, guilty of count 1; counts 2 & 3 dismissed per State's motion.
     Atty. Steiner requests 88-day jail sentence with credit for time served with good time.  Comments on the incident and extensive criminal record.
     Atty. Erickson comments on Iowa case.  Asks recommendation of the State be considered.  
     Def. with no comment.
     Court comments.  Court orders 88 days jail, 66 days credit, court costs to be paid from bond, balance to be paid within 60 days.
9:51 a.m. State files Extradition Complaint (case no. 22-CF-16) on a Winneshiek County warrant.  Def. states understanding and waives his right to extradition.  Court permits waiver of extradition.  
     Court concludes at 9:54 a.m.
